Detailed Description

This class provides a ready-to-use interface for exception handling.

Several macros are provided to make using this Exception class easier. An example is the sthrow() macro, which is designed to replace the normal throw keywoard. 

void Foo::foobar(const Bar & bar) {
     if(bar.myint < 0)
        sthrow(IllegalArgumentException,
           "Cannot foobar() when Bar::myint < 0");
     else {
       // ...
     }
 }
sthrow adds certain debug information, i.e. file and line numbers, if compilation with the debug flag (-DSYLPH_DEBUG) is enabled. Therefore one should prefer sthrow() over throw

To create your own Exception class, use the S_CREATE_EXCEPTION(Name) macro. This will ensure that everything that is required is in your exception. A new class with name 'Name' will be created in the current scope. It extends Sylph::Exception, therefore you can catch all exceptions created with this macro through catch(const Exception& ex).

Two other macros are defined as well, namely strace and straced. These allow you to add trace information to an Exception (i.e. the name of the current function). An example is given below: 

 void foobar() {
     try {
        someDangerousFunction();
     } strace;
 }
straced works similar to strace, but only works when debug mode (-DSYLPH_DEBUG) is enabled.

Two other useful macros are defined, if_nullptr() and check_nullptr(). if_nullptr() works similar to a normal if, but the statements block is only executed when the pointer passed is NULL. However, this macro is more optimized than a normal if. check_nullptr() works similar, but instead of executing a block of code, it will immeadiately throw an NullPointerException.

Sylph::Exception::Exception ( const char *  r = "",
const char *  f = "unknown",
const unsigned int  l = 0 
) throw () [inline]

Creates a new Exception.

You should not use this directly, instead, use sthrow()

Parameters:
r The reason why this Exception got thrown.
f The file this Exception got thrown in.
l The line number on which this Exception got thrown.

virtual Sylph::Exception::~Exception (  )  throw () [inline, virtual]

Default destructor.

Deletes all trace info.

Member Function Documentation

void Sylph::Exception::addTraceMessage ( const char *  message  )  const throw () [inline]

This function adds a message to the trace information inside this Exception.

It can be useful to add the name of a function the Exception passes through (i.e. what strace does), or any other information you like to add to the Exception. This information is purely diagnostic.

Parameters:
message The message to add in the traceinfo log.

virtual const char* Sylph::Exception::name (  )  const throw () [inline, virtual]

Returns the class name of this Exception.

If you used the S_CREATE_EXCEPTION(name) macro, this will be automatically filled in for you. Otherwise you'll have to put in the name yourself. This is purely diagnostic information.

Returns:
The name of the class of this Exception.

Reimplemented in Sylph::ArrayException, Sylph::FileException, Sylph::IOException, Sylph::IllegalArgumentException, Sylph::IllegalStateException, Sylph::NullPointerException, and Sylph::SerializationException.

Returns the reason why this Exception was thrown, i.e. the second parameter to sthrow().

Returns:
The reason why this Exception was thrown.
